conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, creating a dark area on a surface. The size and position of the shadow depend on the angle and distance of the light source relative to the object.
In the image, there are four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D. The light source is currently positioned above these objects, causing the shadows to be cast on the ground.
As the light source moves downward, the angle at which the light hits the objects becomes less steep.

premise: The angle at which the light hits the objects becomes less steep.
conclusion: This generally causes the shadows to become larger because the light is more directly blocked by the objects.
The position of the shadows will shift closer to the base of the objects.

conclusion: As the light source moves downward, shadow A will increase in size.

premise: Shadow A is cast by the object furthest to the left.
conclusion: Shadow A will move closer to the base of the object.
